text: Yeah every spectrum owner had a mate with a C64. The sound and graphics were much better. The sound really was the biggest letdown on the spectrum although it improved massively with 3 channel sound when the 128K came out. You mention Ghostbusters and the spectrum version did NOT come with the end scen graphic on top of the building with the Zuul stuff but did on the C64. As a kid I was devestated when I completed the spectrum version and found that out. I even talked my old man into taking the tape back to the shop as I thought it must be faulty!! You don't know much when you are 10 years old!!

text: <@UUE6E1LA1> Same here - Used to use Susie linux and always found it crap to use as a full windows replacement... these days, I think I'd be able to use Ubuntu Desktop without too much issue. I still prefer linux servers though. Got a linux file server under my stairs hosting all my films/ftp/dev webserver with an uptime of a year or so (only goes down when power needed to be knocked off for building work). Compare that to a windows server I had to do same thing and every install of something needed a reboot or a random crash etc every few months..

text:
I put together a new desktop a few months ago; there was no way I was moving to Win10 so it was time to make the switch to Linux only for me. I came across Entroware and made an enquiry with them since I wanted a bit of customisation from the desktops they offered.

On their About Us page they literally say "No challenge is too big." I asked to use a different case and they wouldn't accommodate. They also didn't list the exact motherboard model (was considering doing some horrible GPU passthru for a Windows VM for gaming and mobos need supporting virtualisation features) and they wouldn't tell me what it was because I might mess around with it and void the warranty? I appreciate getting a laptop is slightly different but it still completely put me off them.

As an aside, gaming on Linux has been surprisingly painless. Lots of games run natively and most that don't run in Steam's Linux runtime or Proton (just an option to select in Steam). The only remaining annoyance is that most anti-cheat software doesn't run on Linux so you can't play certain online games without getting banned. I haven't tried it yet but my plan for those types of games (and anything which isn't compatible) is to go for one of these cloud gaming services like GeForce NOW.

attachments.fallback: [October 14th, 2020 9:50 PM] oddsvantage: I am in the market for a new linux laptop. I came across this place called Entroware which appeals as they deliver to UK. Does anyone have any experience (direct or indirect) with this company? This is what I am thinking of getting <https://www.entroware.com/store/laptops/zeus>  . A couple of positive stories about the place would probably be sufficient for me to pull the trigger on it.

elements.text:
I put together a new desktop a few months ago; there was no way I was moving to Win10 so it was time to make the switch to Linux only for me. I came across Entroware and made an enquiry with them since I wanted a bit of customisation from the desktops they offered.

On their About Us page they literally say "No challenge is too big." I asked to use a different case and they wouldn't accommodate. They also didn't list the exact motherboard model (was considering doing some horrible GPU passthru for a Windows VM for gaming and mobos need supporting virtualisation features) and they wouldn't tell me what it was because I might mess around with it and void the warranty? I appreciate getting a laptop is slightly different but it still completely put me off them.

As an aside, gaming on Linux has been surprisingly painless. Lots of games run natively and most that don't run in Steam's Linux runtime or Proton (just an option to select in Steam). The only remaining annoyance is that most anti-cheat software doesn't run on Linux so you can't play certain online games without getting banned. I haven't tried it yet but my plan for those types of games (and anything which isn't compatible) is to go for one of these cloud gaming services like GeForce NOW.

text: Misses got a new Macbook pro last month. The (UK) plug that it came with wasn't grounded, so if you got it plugged in and charging, touching the metal chassis/or resting hands on it whilst typing causes a feedback vibration in your hands. Apparenty a known issue and main solution is to buy a grounded 2-part charger for £20 (which used to come with previous mac versions but not anymore). Takes the piss..

text: Taking this chat on a slight detour...what flavour of Linux do you AWS people use? I've always been a Debian/xfce fan on my own machines but have more recently started using Mint as it works out if the box, whereas Debian is a bit more "hardcore" and sometimes requires tinkering to get certain hardware drivers working correctly. As I've only recently started using AWS, I opted for Ubuntu on my one and only instance, but am wondering how Amazon Linux performs? Also, I've read that CentOS runs faster than most other distros?
